supporting_text: Resistance to common antibiotics is an issue that cuts across human and animal health, and food, environment and agriculture sectors.
The overarching goal of the Mauritian National Action Plan on Antimicrobial Resistance is to promote and ensure the prudent and judicious use of antimicrobials in the human and agricultural sector.
The NAP includes specific actions related to the veterinary and livestock field, including the promotion of organic farming and training for livestock breeders.
The NAP addresses environmental health through the monitoring of antibiotic residues and the impact of AMR on food safety and security.
The NAP emphasizes the importance of biosecurity and infection prevention in agricultural practices.
A 'Results Management Framework' is proposed for the monitoring and evaluation of the Mauritian NAP on AMR.
The NAP outlines specific strategic objectives with associated timeframes for implementation.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The NAP will be funded by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development to undertake a comprehensive and accurate costing exercise.
The NAP acknowledges resource constraints and outlines a plan for sourcing external funds and prioritizing the NAP in annual budgets.

The multi-sectoral Steering Committee of the Mauritian NAP on AMR has oversight of and is responsible for the development, review, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of the Mauritian NAP on AMR.
The NAP includes actions to review and amend relevant Acts for the optimal procurement, distribution, prescription, and dispensing of antimicrobial medicines.
The NAP includes the development and piloting of a One Health AMR-related curriculum content for primary and secondary schools.
The NAP advocates for the appropriate use of antimicrobials and the containment of AMR using billboards, print, radio, television and social media.
Mauritius is committed to the global action plan on AMR developed by WHO, FAO, and OIE.
The NAP includes the establishment of a National Electronic Surveillance System for antimicrobial use and resistance.
The NAP outlines the need for capacity building in laboratories to process human, animal, and environmental samples.
The NAP includes the establishment of a national infection prevention and control programme for healthcare facilities and communities.
The NAP emphasizes compliance with the standards of the OIE Terrestrial and Aquatic Animal Health Codes and the FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius.
The NAP includes actions to review and enhance the regulations for the registration and procurement of antimicrobials for use in humans and animals.
The NAP includes enforceable regulations to advance AMR prevention and containment.
The NAP outlines the need for research priority setting in AMR, which includes collaboration with international partners.
